Award.AwardTitle: Tropical Intraseasonal Variability in Models and Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding tropical intraseasonal variability is an important problem in climate dynamics. The goal of this project is to enhance understanding of the basic dynamics of the Madden-Julian oscillation (MJO). The broader impacts of this effort are very high. In collaboration with NCAR, the PI will incorporate newly developed process-oriented diagnostics into a diagnostics package that will be applied to different versions of NCAR's Community Earth System Model (CESM) to evaluate--and eventually improve--the representation of the MJO. In addition, there will graduate student and postdoc training as well as the development of diagnostic capabilities that could be used by the climate science community to potentially improve model simulations.

The leading hypothesis that will be examined in this project is that wind-evaporation and radiative feedbacks are required to destabilize the MJO, in conjunction with weakly positive vertical gross moist stability. It is also hypothesized that horizontal advection is critical to eastward MJO propagation. Specific questions that the proposed work will address include: 1) What combination of processes is responsible for destabilization of the MJO, including vertical advection, surface fluxes, and/or radiative feedbacks? 2) What are the contributions of moisture advection by the mean flow, anomalous flow, and higher frequency disturbances to eastward propagation of the MJO? 3) How do selected process-based metrics inspired by the column-integrated MSE budget relate to model MJO performance, and what do these relationships tell us about MJO dynamics? 4) How does the partitioning of destabilization and propagation factors in the column-integrated MSE budget compare between models and observations, and how do differences in this partitioning relate to model mean state bias?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: 

 The Madden-Julian oscillation (MJO) is a region of eastward-moving precipitation that starts in the tropical Indian Ocean and dies in the central Pacific. This precipitation region sends out wind signals not only to other parts of the tropics such as the Atlantic Ocean, but also to North America. These remote wind signatures influence extreme weather events such as hurricanes, cold air outbreaks, hail, tornadoes, and flood events. Prediction of such extreme weather events at leads of 3-4 weeks depends upon the ability to accurately represent the MJO in weather forecasting and climate models.  Improved understanding of what makes the MJO tick fosters model improvement. The present study has substantially improved our understanding of the MJO, its impact on extreme weather events in remote parts of the globe, and how the MJO and its impacts may change in a future warmer climate. In particular, the following key findings were obtained: 

 1) A moist atmosphere supports the precipitation region associated with the MJO. We developed novel diagnostics for tropical moisture exploiting the fact that temperature is relatively uniform across the tropics to show that interactions of clouds and infrared radiation help to maintain the MJO?s moisture source. We also assessed other factors such as surface evaporation and moisture transported by the winds for sustaining the MJO?s moisture source. 

 2) We showed that the remote impacts of the MJO on winds over North America produce a detectable modulation of hail and tornado events, West Coast flooding, and blocked weather regimes in which extreme temperatures and precipitation can develop.  We demonstrated that skillful forecasts of U.S. hail and tornado activity 5-weeks in advance can be made through knowledge of the MJO and its teleconnections. We also explained the mechanism by which the MJO can produce remote wind connections to other parts of the globe. 

 3) We demonstrated that the ability of modern climate models to simulate the MJO?s remote connections to North America is currently limited. Even models that can accurately simulate MJO precipitation in the tropics can produce a poor North American connection because of substantial errors in simulating the jet stream over the North Pacific Ocean. 

 4) Our work used state-of-the-art climate models to examine how the MJO and its connections to North America are projected to change in a future warmer climate. The MJO?s wind variations may decrease in a warmer climate even though tropical precipitation may increase, which would make extreme weather over North America harder to predict at leads of 3-4 weeks. We wrote a review article in Nature Climate Change summarizing the state of recent scientific research on this topic. 

 

Broader Impacts:

This project has contributed to training the next generation of atmospheric scientists. Four graduate students were mentored under this project, included one from an underrepresented background. The project has also contributed to the training of two postdoctoral researchers. Three undergraduate summer interns under a Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at Colorado State University were mentored on work related to this project, including one from an underrepresented group. One of the goals of this research was to improve our understanding of tropical precipitation processes so that we can apply this knowledge to improving our climate and weather forecasting models. Since the MJO perturbs extreme weather across the globe, a better ability to forecast this phenomenon may give stakeholders advanced knowledge of potential extreme weather events that can be used to protect lives and property. For example, the better forecasts of extreme West Coast precipitation we have developed as part of this project may help reservoir managers plan for periods of excessive rainfall and regulate flows into and out of reservoirs accordingly. Similar advanced knowledge of severe weather outbreaks, droughts, and extreme temperatures can be used by other stakeholders. Our results also indicate that the effect of the MJO on these extremes may weaken in future climate, which means that forecast models trained on current climate might need to be modified to account for future climate changes.
